description: I love Jim's came here 2 years ago with some friends. I've been coming here regularly since, The service & food was great, love that retro diner vibe. Waiters are amazing and friendly. The breakfast in this place is GOOOD great selection. My only complaint is that Apple Pay is not accepted here, & I understand it might not be a big deal, but I like to go walletless as often as I can.
author: MacLovin V.

description: So I loved going here with my dad all the time , but a few days ago me dad and brother went and the steak was rotten.They said it smelled so bad that they almost threw up on the table. The told the waitress that they just didn't want to eat anymore that the food was bad. So the pass the bill for the coffee they paid and left. Nice way to make things up
author: Jess M.

description: Morning! Best breakfast place in town. Tired of the over exuberance of "cutting edge" chefs coming up with the latest overpriced brunch fad food you pay $20+ for? No chichi, over the top recipes with house made this and house made that at Jim's. Just good food in a place where your welcomed like old friends coming over for a good meal.
author: John A.

description:
At last I have found a true diner !  Very friendly greeting and excellent breakfast!  Much better than some of the chain diners. 
I have this spot bookmarked.
author: Bruce B.

description: The best place on mission district in  San Francisco for breakfast coffee and relax... Service always friendly
author: Bruno R.

description: This was a nice diner to stop in for breakfast. They had marachi type music playing as we ate. The decorations on the walls and in the bathrooms were unique. Simple, cheap, and basic: it was the perfect place for hangover food. Our food came out quickly and we gobbled it up.
author: Kali P.

description: Came here from Orange County,Ca really loved the French toast breakfast !! Everything was on point and service was nice too! Definitely will come back when I'm in town
author: Franchesca C.

description: Excellent service. Excellent food. Impeccable views and vibe. Very clean Retro theme. Fries are crispy. Ranch is bomb.
author: Mohammad A.

description:
While exploring the area on a Saturday we decided to eat here for lunch. We ordered two coffees and two waters. Eventually had to remind them about the waters, but the coffees came out fast. They only had one choice of sugar on the table, the ones in the pink packets that we didn't want, so we asked if they had anything else. She brought us 4 packs of another sugar. The coffee was not good; very watered down and bland. I didn't have more than a few sips.
I got the chicken sandwich with a house salad instead of fries, which cost extra. He got the steak sandwich with fries. The food came out pretty fast, but was less than impressive. The salad I got was not very fresh but the balsamic dressing was good. The sandwich was pretty basic, I was thankful for the mustard at the table to add some interest. His sandwich was on a roll that was too small and you could probably count on two hands how many fries they gave him. Nothing about the restaurant was memorable, I wouldn't recommend or visit again.
author: Katie H.

description:
If you like breakfast, come here. If you like lunch, come here. If you like dinner, come here. 

It's my Seinfeld diner. 

This place is simple and great.
author: Vanessa P.

description: Excellent traditional breakfast place! I ordered the eggs and bacon. Eggs were cooked perfect and bacon is tasty and crunchy. Pancakes are light and fluffy.  Coffees hot and they serve breakfast all day. Prices are average $10 breakfast is good for the city.
author: Heather O.

description: Jim's is the best greasy spoon diner in SanFrancisco. Period. Affordable, delicious, amazing homey atmosphere.
author: Carolina P.

description: Step back in time, when large comfortable booths, space-age lighting, easy to read menus, and great table service were common...Jim's is fantastic and holds on to that great tradition. I was there for breakfast, steak and eggs with sour dough toast...$15.00 I wouldn't say it's a bargain, and it is on Mission near 20th so the location isn't for everybody...but I thought it was very nice. The location isn't far from a lot of cool parts of the Mission. If you are looking to view some of the beautiful murals painted in the alley ways...super close by. If you are going to The Roxie, shopping for a new Piñata, or just out and about in the most colorful part of the city...try Jim's, I'll be back!
author: Rodney M.

description: Food was great! Service was great! I paid $45 for two omelette plates with hash browns, coffee, coke, and my daughter had French toast with a side of hash browns. Pretty decent! I didn't give it a five because I think every restaurant has room for improvement.
author: Jessica M.

description: Pretty standard diner but I didn't think the quality exactly matched the price.. the waitress seemed very flustered and they ignored a homeless person that wandered in (perhaps that is what you are supposed to do as business owners but I found it a bit sad). I would probably try a new place as opposed to returning here but it's a very solid option in the books!
author: Katy S.

description: I love this place. It's got soul. The women that work there are amazing and so welcoming and warm. The food is good comfort food, the green salsa and hash browns are my favorite. If you need a friendly, family vibe place- definitely check out Jim's. Much love to Jim's and deep thank you for the good vibes and heart!
author: Maria M.

description: This place is basically the most average coffee shop of all time. Nothing stood out, but not terrible. Totally, totally average. Probably wouldn't go back unless this place was the only place open.
author: Aaron A.

description:
New Owners of Jim' Restaurant are Chinese!

That being said, you do not get the "Real Diner Experience!" The food was below average and the serving portions where tiny! Everything tasted "freezer burned!" Coffee was watered down! Even the Ketchup bottles are watered down! 

The Chinese Lady (Owner) was very curt and unprofessional! 

Eat at your own risk!
author: Jesse J.

description: One morning, I had a craving for corn beef hash & eggs. Been living in the area for almost 30 yrs but don't know any restaurant close by that serves them. I went to yelp & searched for  the nearest one. It says Jim's just within walking distance. The food was delicious even my picky grandsons were delighted. The corn beef hash & hash brown we're served crunchy just the way I wanted them & my grandsons Mickey Mouse pancakes were hot & fluffy.  The servier was fast & very polite plus the prices are affordable. I will come back for sure & will recommend it to friends & family.
author: Dorcas C.

description: Love this place! I go here for breakfast all the time I work a block away. Everyone's is super sweet. You know You're an SF native when you see a picture of a family member on the wall lol. If you're in the area stop by you won't be disappointed.
author: Sasha M.

description: Best cheap and cheerful breakfast and brunch around here. Be warned: it is a diner so might not be your thing. But if it is, wow, the pancakes are top notch. The atmosphere and staff are friendly and food is great.
author: Michael C.

description: Ambience a bit rough but food and service met expectations.  The garlic in the green chili sauce!
author: Lawrence T.

description: Jim's Restaurant is our go-to place. It's simple, good food. Everyone there is so welcoming and kind! We've gotten to know them over the countless times dining here. Non-expensive. Recommend to visitors and everyone! Cute little breakfast spot. I only wish they were open later!
author: Grace L.

description:
I've walked by Jim's Restaurant for years. But today I was on a mission for Chicken Fried Steak.  I was not disappointed! For $11.95 you get a good sized CFS smothered in gravy, two eggs to order, a pile of hash browns and your choice of toast.
I loved the divey diner decor. This place must have been around for 50 or more years
author: Shane C.

description:
Coming here for brunch one day was like briefly departing SF for a more homely feel. Being inside of this diner restaurant felt both strange and relaxing, because it is no longer the type of place I'm "used to" eating at up here, and yet, it's smack dab in the hot spot on Mission Street. Was a nice, almost secret getaway for us.

For my meal, I ordered the Country Breakfast, with the French Toast Substitute, Eggs Sunny Side Up and Bacon. Beverage was an Iced Café Mocha. The entire meal was decent diner flair. I enjoyed it, added Tobasco to my bacon and eggs, syrup to my French Toast, and the gobbles came not from the turkey. It was all it needed to be.

Very inexpensive, too. Kind of like a mini Inland Empire spot within The City. Why can't more meals in SF be priced like this? I intend to be back.
author: Garett T.

description:
Jim's is a complete and utter dive. Torn upholstery in the booths, dim lighting, chipped glasses, comic sans on the menus, the whole nine yards.

However, the food isn't half bad. I mean, it's not Mission-trendy, but it knows what it is. The jumbo scramble is quite big and not runny, and the hash browns aren't too crispy. If you know what you're getting into, then you're gonna have a good time.
author: Casey S.

description: So I came here with my lady and the service was nice prompt.  We ordered coffee I didn't really like it . It seemed like the coffee had been sitting there for a while. We both got the bisquits and gravy 2 eggs and fruit salad. The bisquits and gravy were great added a bit of pepper for my liking my lady said it didn't nerd no seasonings. The eggs were cooked perfect. The fruit salad was cold and crisp, it had water melon ,oranges apples and can slope in it. It. Was great .
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Jim's has been around since before I was born (I'm 35). I recently came here to have breakfast and loved the service. Our waitress was super friendly and fast, she was the only one waitressing. We ordered our food and it came out in less than 10 minutes. Super fast for hungry people. Our food was fresh, hot and delicious.
We came back again recently and had the same wonderful experience. 

I hope this hidden gem will not be closed down, burned down or taken over by the yuppie movement in the mission.
author: Carolina M.

description:
I've been curious about this place for ages since I'm hardly ever in the Mission when this place is open. I've passed by it many times, but they close at 3:30PM every day even though they sell Dinner Specials. Who eats Baby Beef Liver with Grilled Onions? Night watchmen just off their graveyard shift? Insomniac prostitutes after a slow night? Bulimic hipsters on a binge? I was just looking for some breakfast last Saturday after taking the car out to go to the post office. I'm amazed at the paucity of options in my immediate neighborhood, so I found myself in the Mission and got giddily excited to find a parking space at 20th and Mission.

I was surprised to see how bustling it was at 10AM since I'm so used to seeing it deserted and dark from the outside. It looks and feels like any Roadside Diner, U.S.A., a place you are more likely to find off a highway in the Central Valley than in the heart of hipsterville. But I assume that's part of its lure, the anachronistic presence of a formica-heavy diner with no mention of a burrito, pupusa or organic sushi on the menu. What I did find intriguing is that they offer a Hangtown Fry and other seafood dishes you don't really expect here. The booths were filled with boisterous families, so I secured an empty seat at the far counter without any fuss. The waitresses were buzzing by with purpose.

I ordered the $6.75 Big Scramble because I was in the mood for a Joe's Special-type of breakfast. It was serviceable - a solid portion of ground beef mixed with scrambled eggs and bits of sauteed onions and green peppers, accompanied by hashed browns that gratefully looked like they didn't come out of a package (see photo) and of course, two slices of already buttered toast which came with lots of those little berry and mixed fruit jam packages. There was definitely a lot of butter and vegetable oil in everything they make, but that's what you expect anyway. But then again, I found it more digestible than anything I've ordered at Sparky's or Golden Coffee Shop. Staff is friendly but not in a kiss-mah-grits kind of way.

FOOD - 3 stars...greasy diner fare satisfies if you're in the mood
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...roadside formica in the middle of the Mission
SERVICE - 3 stars...friendly but not too much
TOTAL - 3 stars...not bad for what it is
author: Ed U.

description:
this place is still the best!!! The OWNERS HAVE NOT CHANGED. They are not "all Chinese"- in fact, none of them are. They are closed on Sundays though.

Highlights: beef soup with their house special green sauce on Saturdays and the hard to find Hangtown Fry bfast with the green sauce on it also, rice instead of hashbrowns for the simple egg bfast is also great, with soy sauce on the rice and the ever popular green sauce. Yes, that green sauce is incomparable.
author: kim y.

description:
It was great to find a no-nonsense diner amidst all the hipster, frufru establishments. If you want simple, delicious, filling food at a reasonable price, then this would be a good choice. 

My only critique is that they could have used another server on the floor.
author: Jason F.

description: This place is the worst (food). The ingredients are the cheapest.  How can you ruin a basic breakfast. The chicken fried steak was mushy. Yes mushy! Soaked in oil and dissolved in your mouth.... I don't think steak should do that. The staff is friendly and quick. The inside needs refreshing big time. A tad bit dirty.
author: Jason P.

description:
Keep in mind "greasy spoon".... But if you need delicate dining where your food looks like a van Gogh and everything comes with a side of air, go to a five star brunchery. 

Food is good and the price is right.
author: Darth M.

description:
3.5 stars really. I can always find a seat here and get a decent breakfast. Nothing fancy. Waffles, bacon, sunny side up eggs, oj in plastic cups, you get the idea. I like coming here because it's a real neighborhood joint and I can order food without multi-syllable adjectives and descriptors. 

You won't find long lines here. 

There no hipster pour overs or cold brews, in fact I'm certain that words such as single origin, small batch, crafted, artisanal don't appear anywhere. Don't expect driftwood tables lit by Edison bulbs or any such pretense ambiance. 

Do take delight in the fact that highway robbery priced toast and butter selections are not on the menu.
author: Charles L.

description: This place is great.They h s ve good service and they can whoop up some grub in a minuye.I Definitely recommend this place for a quick brunch/breakfast
author: Percy G.

description: Great breakfast food and friendly service. Its a gem in the mission. Love this place!
author: R T.

description: One of my favorite mom n pop dives in the Mission. Been going for years and they've always had the same staff  (definitely not because they're blood relatives), speaks volumes. Fast service, pleny of food and always a bottomless cup of coffee!
author: Steph R.

description:
As a Texas expatriate, I am always on the lookout for a decent chicken fried steak. This is the best I've found in the city. why is it so difficult for everybody else? Proper fried steak, proper cream gravy with sausage chunks. Yes.

Really nice staff and the same faces every time I am here. Well prepared American diner food. Go here if you are in the Mission and hungover.
author: stephan k.

description: Best people and best food! I'm glad people come here expecting all the bells and whistle and are disappointed. Hopefully they won't return so their regulars can appreciate this golden spot all the more! Keep it up jims! We love you guys!
author: Rebecca R.

description:
VALUE.
Service.
Soul.
Killer green salsa!
Real people.
Real San Francisco!
Nuff  Said.
author: Mag N.

description: I stopped into Jim's yesterday. It was not busy and when I walked into the restaurant the waitress gestured for me to take a seat at a booth. I sat down, figured out what i wanted and waited. There was only one waitress and she was not really busy so I was a bit surprised that a few minutes later I was still sitting there and she had not taken my order. Then a man came in and sat down. She walked past my table, brought him a glass of water and took his order right away. I walked over to her and asked her why she had ignored me. If she had just apologized for ignoring me I would have sat back down but she shrugged and said she did not see me. She is the one that told me where to sit and she walked by my table several times. I told her I am not eating here today and will not be coming back. She shrugged and said "OK". Still no apology. I pick where I spend my money and will never eat at a place where I am not treated nicely.
author: Cray T.

description:
Good breakfast, really good prices and convenient location. 
The interior however was more than disturbing. Carts with dirty dishes everywhere, moldy smell and the waitress sitting down at a table to eat while she was working. 
I was warned not to use the restrooms, so I can't say how bad it really was.
author: Caroline K.

description: Ordered a sandwich and the crap damn near gut my mouth!!! The owner stood right in front watching me eat!! Like I'm going to haul ass out the restaurant without paying?!!  What a weirdo!!  Everything in Jim's restaurant needs some HOLY WATER!!  This place sucks, won't be coming back!!
author: Scooby S.

description:
Come on guys.. This is exactly why I try to stick to my rule of 4 Yelp stars and up. This place was not good man..I feel kind of bad leaving a low review since the Asian( or light skinned Hispanic) lady seemed really sweet however..

Ordered the country scramble

Eggs- buttery and pretty good
Pancakes- really spongey and dense..
Bacon-so I never send food back but this was just bad..tasted like old meat? Trust me I eat bacon everyday so I know what bacon is supposed to taste like.

Denny's and ihop are better.. Just sayin
author: Tony P.

description: Not sure why any negative reviews. This place is a down home diner through and through. The staff is lovely, the service quick, and the food exactly what it should be. Maybe not trendy/gourmet enough for some yupsters? But if you want a solid breakfast that won't push you over $15 bucks with tip in the Mission, this is it. Also, I could eat that house made green salsa by the cup full. So good.
author: Arthur G.

description:
This is a classic diner spot in the Mission. The vintage booths and counter create a homey atmosphere which is perhaps the best part of the experience. The food itself is nothing elaborate but definitely solid and tasty american brunch. The food was a good value given the low prices and hefty portions. 

Pro-tip: ask for the green salsa. Then put it on everything. Flavorful and delicious, it puts a kick on what could otherwise be a bland breakfast.

EDIT: I'm  upping this from 3 to 4 stars just because Jim's ages well on a person. It's become my favorite place for a lazy Sunday morning.
author: Claire G.

description: Great value for the food that I got.  Pancakes are decent and the scrambles are great.  Plus the coffee just keeps coming and coming =)
author: Warriors F.

description:
My prior review wasn't wrong, but it missed the big draw of Jim's that's kept me coming back for...oh god 50+ checkins. That's the staff.

I'm a weekend guy, here around noon on Saturdays and Sundays. That means Miss Kim up front and Ingrid and Jamila working the tables. This team is funny and friendly, just what you want out of a cozy diner. They don't mind me dawdling over a good book and the coffee keeps coming. 

So when you are looking for something friendly that reminds you of home, drop by Jim's and sit at the counter a few times. They're busy but friendly and you might just find yourself a regular.
author: Scott T.

description:
The food is delicious and they serve you generous quantities! Sure, the decor is old but the service is prompt and friendly. I really enjoyed my experience here. They played throwbacks on the radio and it was a quiet and calm environment. Definitely worth a try if you are in the neighborhood and don't want to break the bank for some good comfort food. 

Note: I came here on a Tuesday afternoon and ordered breakfast.
author: Wendy M.

description:
I had such high hopes for this place because I LOVE retro diners. In terms of ambiance, this place fits that mold perfectly. The diner-style counters, the old booths, being able to see into the kitchen... love it. The service was also great-- very attentive and very nice. Sadly, the food just wasn't up to snuff. I am no snob when it comes to diner food, but they really let me down. 

First of all, the coffee is TERRIBLE! I can drink Folgers with the best of them, but their coffee is just absolutely disgusting. I've never had coffee so bad. Really, a diner can get away with almost anything as long as they have good coffee. You'd think they would be able to address that...

I ordered the country breakfast, which comes with two eggs, meat, and pancakes (you can substitute a waffle for the pancakes for 2 bucks, which I did). The waffles by themselves cost $5 and are definitely pre-made and frozen. Mine was flat, hard as a board, and cold when they brought it out. In fact, none of my food (except the coffee) came out hot. It's strange, because I could see them preparing it... maybe they put everything on cold plates or something? Even the eggs, I ordered them sunny-side up, were not hot. For two bucks more I added an order of hash browns. Their hash browns are nothing more than grated potatoes. They don't add onion, peppers, ANYTHING. Very plain. Thankfully they had some green salsa on the counter that I was able to cover them with.

One thing I noticed is that this place actually serves sausage patties instead of sausage links, which is cool... I ordered the bacon as my meat, and was happy to find that you get 4 slices instead of the typical 2.

All in all, this place just doesn't cut it for me. Very sad, because I really love the way the place is designed.
author: P U.

description: Horrible Pancakes HORRIBLE Service. The servers were so rude !! Now I know why the restaurant was so empty! I will never go there again! Plus my bill was 18.00 for a meal that tasted like it came out of a microwave- I have served before and I tip good but believe me, my tip to them is to get into a different line of work!!
author: Mikayla S.

description:
This is a super old school diner, with oversized black leather booths and a bar to sit at. The food is good and reasonably priced, and the service is friendly and efficient. No complaints here.

Their bathroom, on the other hand is the filthiest dump I have EVER laid my eyes on in a restaurant. I would prefer the average gas station bathroom over this catastrophe. It's bad enough to take an entire star off my rating, and I'm being generous here.
author: Chris W.

description: Me and my boyfriend decided to stop at this place he ordered the combination seafood (horrible choice) it looked like it came straight from the freezer only one shrimp and vegetables looked out of the can! Best suggestion go to Denny's it's not worth what you pay for the food you get!
author: Brenda O.

description: Good breakfast love the hours and location nice services and the host are just amazing.
author: Suvagal R.

description:
After spending an entire morning ODing on sweets with a friend at nearby Tartine and Bi-Rite, we were in dire need of something savory. And what better than a breakfast/brunch place? Fortunately, I came in here with the understanding that Jim's was more or less a diner: which, for me, means that the food is usually somewhere between mediocre and average.

Jim's fell toward a bit more towards the positive end of that scale. Ordering myself a corned beef hash, I was greeted more or less with what I expected. Fairly large servings of average tasting, greasy food, for a reasonable price (a.k.a. not super cheap, yet not terribly pricey). I can't see myself coming here again though, given the much tastier eats in the area. But, hey, it's there for when you really need it, and I've been to far worse places.

And, while this had no bearing on service, my friend and I were amused that we were the only two Asians in the entire restaurant at 11am.
author: Johnny W.

description: It's one of those "it is what it is" places. Had the ground beef scramble with hash browns and wheat toast.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
A friend of mine was going to have brunch after church with one of her high school friends and invited me to tag along. She seemed excited about this place and made sure I remembered "Jim's."

I walked up to this place, and it's a very unassuming breakfast joint. If my friend didn't make a point to check this place out, I would've walked right by and never noticed it.

But I'm glad my friend did. You walk inside and it's just a typical old-skool breakfast diner with linoleum booths and muted 70's colors. The waitstaff was friendly and food came out quickly.

My friend ordered the country fried steak and I got the french toast. The country fried steak reminded me of Texas... perfectly fried without being too greasy or salty, covered in white gravy. My friend also got eggs over easy, which made the yolk and gravy mixture perfect. My french toast was delicious! They used thicker pieces of (what tasted like) potato bread, and the sweet and savory mixture was perfect. And what made the breakfast really great was that they gave us a MIXING BOWL of jalapenos. No one would ever be in need for those delicious peppers!

Prices were very reasonable and the restaurant was pretty clean. I would definitely stop by again!
author: Becky K.

description: Jim's always makes my day with the friendly staff and great food.  4 generations of family and the owners know each one
author: Tracy B.

description: Anytime you need a regular breakfast,  no frills, just local people from the hood, this is it.  Bacon and eggs always cooked and served correctly.   The Big Scramble is like a Joe special, just add Spinach for $1.20.  They still poach eggs.  I had to tell the staff to stop refilling my coffee.   They are like.old school, if you can't respect that, it's on you.
author: Rey D.

description:
I been here few times; I usually like to get their breakfast platter with scrabble eggs, wheat toast and sausage the favor its "good" but its fair for the price $5.99. I have try their turkey club sandwich which comes with fries and a very small soup cup, which it also taste "good"

Customer Service its excellent, I think one of the waitress has work at Jim's for almost 30  years and she is well known by the costumer.
author: Eryckah G.

description: Great Breakfast, fresh, large portions, quick, and nice service.  Nice atmosphere. Only con was the restroom was upstairs and my 70 year old father couldn't manage the steps.
author: Ann N.

description: My Girlfriend, son and I loooove Jim's! They're food is great! Not only is their food good but they treat you like family when you're there. My 2 year old son is a super picky eater but at Jim's he eats everything because it's that good.
author: Chris E.

description:
Boogaloo's had a big ole waiting list. We weren't in the mood for fancy, we just wanted some basic American brekkies like Eggs Benedict. What's that you say, Yelp app? Jim's Restaurant? Two blocks away? Woohoo!!  Let's go!

The service was good, the plates were just what you'd expect - my girlfriend cleared her benedict so fast, I couldn't get a taste!

Jim's is pretty big - bigger than you'd realize from the low-profile storefront. It's your basic diner, vinyl booths, formica tabletops, see-through window to the kitchen. The food's not going to blow your mind, but that's OK, you probably wanted to keep your mind intact, right?
author: alex j.

description:
Fast. Friendly. Freaking awesome!

The food is delicious: boyfriend had the country fried steak, and I had a waffle with fresh fruit, and bacon. Country fried steak that satisfies said boyfriend is hard to find, so I was pretty relieved when Jim's was right up his alley. It came with sourdough toast, country potatoes, and egg. Perfect serving size too! My waffle was just the right crisp to soft ratio, and it came with fresh strawberries, and bacon!! Yum. To top it off the coffee was great, too! But the best part? The service. Quick, friendly and efficient. 

Overall, fantastic experience. :)
author: Stefanie A.

description:
Wait staff was very nice, tables clean and the food was ready fast, portion size was pretty big.

BUT!! The food is truly disgusting in here...
Hashbrown has never seen potatoes, they probably use the cheapest ready-meal shit from Cisco, not sure. Tastes like flour.
Hollandaise sauce was the same, nasty. 
Nothing was made from scratch!
French toast had no taste, basically a big dry sponge...
Seats are rundown, floor dirty, silverware unacceptably old and disgusting!
Menu was sticky and torn.
Not coming back
author: Daniella V.

description: The food was good the staff was nice and respectful.  The bathroom looked really dirty  and filled with graffiti the toilet paper was wet.  The restaurant has nice prices for food.
author: Davon T.

description: Not bad, came in for a quick bite to eat and that's exactly what it was. Good burger and fries for a very decent price.
author: Luis H.

description:
Service here is a real treat. Nice folks!
The old skool counter and banquettes are refreshing as well.
2 eggs sunny side up with thick bacon, hashbrowns, rye toast and coffee... this is my spot in the Mission!
Coffee ain't bad for percolated either!
author: Josh K.

description: Every time I walk in this place I feel like I'm in a Quentin Tarrantino movie, except with much more hospitality, not to mention the best homemade green salsa in a sawed-off squeeze bottle on the planet.
author: Kmc M.

description:
If you are looking for a simple breakfast place with no muss or fuss then this is the place for you. Totally a neighborhood joint with no pretense and friendly servers. 

Unlike other "greasy spoon diners", the food has never been greasy. Scrambled eggs were fluffy and the hashbrowns were perfect (I order mine extra-crispy because crunchy hashbrowns are best).

Never crowded and always comfortable. This is not the place to go to if you want organic shade-grown goat-pooped peruvian coffee,  infused champagne mimosas or frangipane croissants.

It is the place to go to if you just want a good basic breakfast.
author: Will N.

description:
Um okay not the cute kitschy experience I was hoping for but here's how my story goes. I dropped in for a late lunch at about 2:30ish on a Wednesday afternoon, I was alone but had high hopes because of all the intrigue of reviews on yelp. I notice their lunch special listed on in the window, Chicken Teriyaki, I know this is not a Japanese noodle house but my instinct just wanted to give this 'ole diner a try. There was only one other patron in here she looked like she had a decent dine, so why shouldn't I? 

Here's where it got weird. I don't know what affiliation they had with the restaurant, but this one little Latino man was leaning against the glass, does the "looking in" thing with his hands and then starts texting on his phone. I sat in the booth right up front so I couldn't help but to peer out toward the streets while I waited for my order. He then popped into the Restaurant and yelled something to the cook, maybe just saying hello? Maybe he worked there, knew someone there, I really just don't know. 

The only other woman in there just finished her meal, she just left some cash on the table, her bill had not arrived yet.  So now I was the sole patron in the establishment.
 
Another little man passes the restaurant... then backtracks sticks his face in the window from the booth that I am stationed at, he then enters the restaurant then hangs over the booth that I am seated at.  Okay at this point I am feeling super uncomfortable like I was in middle of some kind of inner sting operation, and sure enough through the window I see a truck slowing down, the random stranger who was hanging over my booth let's out a shrill whistle as the driver of the truck pauses.   Sketchy little guy wheels a fancy land cruiser bike on to the back of the truck, and then the truck screeches off down Mission street.  Dude gives me a look of death just as bad as shaking a finger in my face and saying, I saw nothing. 

Then my food arrived, I took a few bites then was just so bothered that I completely lost my appetite, the bill was about 7 dollars so I threw ten on the table, waved to the waitress and just hi tailed the eff outta there.  

Sorry not coming back... ever.
author: B H.

description:
The soup of the day is homemade/housemade and delicious.   Get that instead of a salad.

Super cheap food and a great staff.  I always end up tipping 30-35 percent because the prices are so low and the service is so great.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Needed a quick breakfast stop in the Mission.  Place was very plain, nothing fancy not even the silverware but the sausage and egg/hash browns and toast were great and flavorful.  Fast and friendly service.
author: John K.

description:
Before falling asleep I thought "man I really hope he wants to get breakfast tomorrow morning." 

Next thing I know, I'm waking up and he wants breakfast! Yipee! Except I was hoping breakfast would just appear in front of me. Instead of me running around the Mission, picking up the breakfast, and hoping not to run into anyone while I'm wearing a shirt three sizes too big as he took a leisurely shower. 

So here is the crazy part. Ready? I once had a best friend named Flavia. Then I moved and I lost her number. Flavia also doesn't have internet and I literally lost all communication with her. Fast forward 4 years later as I'm running into Jim's Restaurant with my hair flying around everywhere. I go to pay the woman at the register and next to the register is a column with family photographs all over it and whose face is plastered all over these photos? FLAVIA! It was such a trip I couldn't even believe it. Haha. I asked the woman if she knew who was in the photos and she just responded with "Thats Maria's daughter." Crazy. Isn't it? 

Oh and the food was mediocre. My waffle was drowning in melted butter when I opened the take out box. It was rubbery and they didn't have sugar free syrup. Eggs were average. I didn't think it was that cheap either but it was the only place open.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
OK place to have a meal 
food is OK not perfect 
need to make food more taste and delicious!
author: Jimmy M.

description: I've walked past this place a hundred times and always wonder about it.  Well wonder no more. Once you step inside it feels like you step back in time. Sat at the counter with a friend and within a few minutes we were greeted with a gracious female waiter that make us feel welcome. We were served coffee immediately. My friend ordered the Denver omelet and I the scrambled eggs with diced ham. Both plates were scrumptious and the hash brown were done to perfection. We both left our plates clean. Coffee was good but it could be a little bit stronger, but that is me. This review is only for their breakfast, but I want to come back and try their other lunch or dinner plates. Close at  3pm, dinner plates is part of their regular hours too.
author: Hum V.

description: This is my favorite diner in SF. The food is great, service is fast and attentive, everything is very clean, and you will never have an empty cup of coffee while eating -- something nearly impossible to find in SF. It reminds me of your local NYC diner.
author: Kurt F.

description:
This is good as it gets.

I come here religionsly and have to admit, I have ordered almost everything on the menu and never have had a complain.  The waitress are always friendly, cheering and make the experience great.  

I have to give a shout out to Ingrid, Jamila and Mari who have always serve coffee with a smile and never leave your cup running dry.
author: Isis L.

description: Has a real down home vibe to it and has had one since I've been a kid and even before that according to the mission OGs. Mornings and lunches here have treated me well throughout the years. It really takes you back to a simpler time. Sure beats the hell outta Boogaloos. Jim pimp slaps Boogaloos.
author: Lucy F.

description: Jims is disgusting. I thought this was really good until i came. The menus are stained this place needs a real update. I ordered a cheeseburger. The lettuce was  basically left out to rot. It had brown edges stating it wasn't even fresh. My friend ordered orange juice and she told the waiter it tasted weird. The waiter replied "I'm sorry but we just made it. I was disappointed since a regular restaurant would get a new cup of juice but she didn't . Never coming back after this experience. If there was a zero star i would give it that
author: Tiffany T.

description:
I went here with my roommate for Saturday "brunch." 

We didn't know our destination when we started wandering around the Mission. My expectations were typical for SF brunch: find someplace trendy on Valencia, wait in line for an hour, sit down to an expensive but tasty meal with rushed service. Sometimes these experiences are worth it for the deliciousness, conversation, and/or SF street cred, but in general I prefer to eat something satisfying & fast so I can go do other stuff with my free time. Jim's is perfect for that.

We were seated immediately, ordered within the first few minutes, and got our food before we noticed we'd been waiting. I ordered the avocado, onion, and cheese omelet with hashbrowns. The food itself was greasy but very tasty and cheap. And it wasn't overly greasy -- Jim's does a good job calibrating expectations with the mid-20th century diner decor :)

The only thing that really bothered me was the noise from the espresso machine, but I can avoid that next time by sitting near the windows.

I live only a few blocks away and expect to return again soon!
author: Max H.

description:
A-OK is right on. 

i needed some fuel before a tattoo appt - and we stumbled upon Jim's. 

retro li'l joint - with a neighborhoody vibe. 

the food was cheap, and sufficient. 

service was friendly and fast. 

no real complaints here. 

this place hits that greasy spoon spot. i would definately stop in again.
author: Nik N.

description:
June 15 Breakfast

Jim's s a diner, your average greasy spoon in the Mission. The decor has seen better days but the leather booths are spacious and comfy. Foodwise it's nothing compared to the nearby Red Cafe, which serves up huevos racheros and various scramblers.

At Jim's, for very good prices you get the basic: ham and eggs, omelets, sausage and bacons. On this morning I had the mushroom, onion and cheese omelet--average tasting and steamy hot. They are generous with the mushroom. Half the plate is hash brown which I couldn't finish, let alone the two slices of sourdough buttered toasts.

Make sure you get the "green sauce" which gives a nice kick and edge to the flavor of the food. The lady who waited on me is very friendly and always checked on my coffee. 

Omelet and coffee $10
author: Matt Y.

description: ate her a few time good value but not open 24 hours that would be great san francisico needs more 24 hour restraunts
author: Leigh G.

description:
For $5.05 you get two eggs, a ton of hashbrowns, toast and BACON.  Much higher quality than Waffle House.  How does that not deserve 5 stars?

Coffee is good for a diner.  You can have as many jalapenos as you want.

I am surprised at the low rating for this place.
author: Quags M.

description:
Let me preface this critique by stating that I'm not the biggest fan of diners and hole-n-the wall's! 
I don't hate them it's just that generally the poor food and service is not worth my time. If I'm going to spend money eating out I may as well spend a little more and get what I want.
So I was not the most thrilled when my buddy Miles wanted to go here for breakfast. 

So we came here yesterday to have a greasy-spoon type breakfast. Miles semi-raved about this place before we arrived and I figured why not? If it's as good as any Denny's then I should be just fine with whatever I ordered.
The joint was bustling with the typical eclectic mix of Mission types. You know, Latino families, Hipsters, yuppies etc. 
So when we arrived we noticed that the counter was relatively empty and we asked if we could take a seat. There was no hostess and the waitress's' were too busy to really help out. 
We took our seat and one of the waitress's was right there waiting to take our order. Perfect! Let's order! So we did.
Well, we ended up waiting a little over a half hour (seriously) for our order. That would not have been such a bad thing but two little old men arrived (separately) about 10 minutes and 15 minutes (respectively) after we did and both of them got their breakfast way before us!
Not only this, but a table of 3 construction workers arrived about 10 minutes after we did and they got their order a few minutes before we did. 
I asked the waitress if they forgot our order and she said that they were short staffed in the back. 
Yeah, right.
If they were short staffed then why was everyone's order coming out before ours? And in a timely manner. 
I honestly think that she forgot to put our order in or they forgot to cook it. It's the only thing that could explain why it would take a half hour to fry up a Hangtown Fry and a veggie benedict. It's not brain surgery! It's fried food for God's sake!
Needles to say I will never come back and I should have gone with my first instinct. Which is for me to stay away from diners.
They are just a waste of time.
author: Gabe T.

description:
I've been looking for an acceptable diner in this city for a while, and I finally found it: Jim's!

They had the only acceptable chicken-fried steak I've found.

I only wish that they were open for 24-hours so I can eat unhealthily after drinking.
author: Noel V.

description: Best place on earth! The meal proportions are huge! Their milkshakes are the most amazing thing ever, the food all in all is incredible. Great place to have a birthday breakfast or a get together. The staff is very nice, friendly faces. Though sometimes you do have to wait for a table, its worth the wait.
author: Giselle P.

description:
My friend and I usually try out different cafes and diners for breakfast or brunch on the weekends and this morning I chose Jim's. Since Jim's has a 4-Star Rating on yelp, I was expecting to have some yummy greasy diner food. Unfortunately, it was quite disappointing.

As far as food goes, it's more a 2/3-Star Rating but the service was friendly and pleasant, so I'll round it off to 3. My friend and I both got the Country Breakfast Combo which comes with 2 eggs, choice of meat, toast or upgrade to waffle, pancake, or french toast. I got mine with the Waffle and my friend got the French Toast with it. Both were very blah-tasting and my Waffle was even still undercooked inside. And the over-medium eggs I requested were still too runny for my taste. Coffee tasted like crap but that I expected. The most enjoyable thing we had was the side of Hash Browns that we requested Crispy--that one they got right.

If I'm in the neighborhood, I may give it another try but for sure will not get the French Toast or Waffle.
author: Barbra C.

description:
Went here for breakfast based on a friend's recommendation. I ordered the vegetarian omelette. My friend ordered the salsa, which was an amazing vampire repelling green garlic filled salsa that went extraordinarily well with the omelette an hash browns.

We enjoyed our brunch at noon on a rainy San Francisco Sunday when it wasn't too crowded. Check out the breakfast, and especially for the green salsa.
author: Kendall C.

description:
Great service, almost great food. The homemade green salsa is garlicky heaven. Love the booths. This has now replaced our family's Sunday morning breakfast go to. We used to go to Al's but they suck now.
It is Sunday morning, guess where we are of to?
author: Sara S.

description:
Did you just wake up slightly hung over and in need of some breakfast noms?  Don't wanna wait in a huge ass line at one of the many outstanding brunch spots in the city?  Then for a good solid hangover-busting meal, Jim's is your spot!

I  went with Laura W. here last Sunday and it's a nice chill old-school vibe in here.  It feels like you are transported to the late 70s by the decor and such.  Food is pretty solid and Laura said the coffee was good so what else do ya need?
author: Gene X.

description:
Love this place! 
Its standard diner food and they arent stingy with the coffee. They have a pretty good variety and the staff is great.
author: Kara H.

description: Jim's is a perfect place to cure a hangover! The portions are generous and help soak up wine and gin martinis.... plus 20 mins. in. when you realize you spent  $$$ the night before, you wont feel bad at all b/c :  A.  You're drinking apple juice, and B. pancakes are coming! In conclusion, everything I've tried here has been great! I typically get the CBH and it comes out perfect--crispy and incredibly unhealthy every time. If you're a waffle person get here before noon, as they stop serving them after then. Lastly, dont forget to ask for the green salsa.
author: Tate P.

description:
whoever is rating this place below 4 or 5 is smoking something.

This is the best Chicken Fried Steak I've had in the city; top 3 in the bay area. I've tried 3 different locations - hard knox, bob's, lucky penny for the CFS but this is the only one that has truly come through.

coffee is delish, staff is friendly and attentive. 

and i see one tip that it's cash only. it is definitely not cash only.

hence, my hypothesis yelp raters are smoking is affirmed.
author: Victor B.

description: One staff member took the day off because she was sick, sat next to me at the counter, and talked loudly to the chef about her symptoms. Another staff member eating on the job asked a co- worker if the green salsa was still good, she said she thought it was and asked that I hand her the green salsa I just used. My corned beef hash was clearly spam (gross) and the toast was stale.
author: Greg K.

description:
I only recently saw this place on my way to work up Mission, and I noticed that it was really close to La Taza, which I frequent on my lunch breaks. I decided that it looked good and wanted to try it out.

I am very pleased with Jim's. It really isn't a restaurant, per se. It's more of, as others have noticed, a diner/cafe/coffee shop. I love the counter, I love the booths. The big plate glass windows onto Mission are awesome, too. Very Nighthawks. To top it off, they have excellent vintage Mission District photos (circa 1920's, 30's) showing what a car free (OK, car diminished) Mission looked like. Sorry, showing my anti-motor coach stripes now ...

The prices seem very reasonable, but keep in mind you're not getting frog's legs here. The place was also clean, which is always nice. The bathroom arrangement is a little odd, with you having to go out the back door and then travel up stairs to use the facilities. I think, due to this situation, there is an inordinate amount of graffiti from the local gangs proclaiming their turf. But hey, it adds character.
author: Wes T.

description:
So everything is about this place is average:
The eggs are good...not great.
The pancake are decent.
The hash browns - let's be real, if any diner screws up hash browns, that's an automatic 1 star.
author: Zahir A.

description:
Jim's is one of those classic greasy spoons.

My girlfriend and I went for lunch, and the place was filled w/ locals whom the staff knew the orders of by heart. One guy came in and basically had a burger in hand by the time he sat down.

The staff was super friendly, and the food was good. It didn't blow my mind, but it was quality, and about the right price. Lunch for both me and my girlfriend was just over $15.
author: Nick S.

description:
Prices are cheap, place is clean, service is friendly, and the food is good for the price. 

Was probably an American Classic when American Classics weren't a marketing scheme. 

My eggs, sausage, hash browns, and toast were done in under 5 minutes. 

Much less skeevy and "frontish" than Silvercrest on Bayshore.  And a helluva lot cheaper too.
author: Ricky P.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning as both Boogaloos and Mission Beach Cafe had a crowd of people outside. :( There was no line or wait, so Jim's it was.

FOOD: I love Cornbeef hash, but Jim's only serves it during dinner--boo hoo! So, I decided to order the Country Breakfast with 2 pancakes, sunnyside up eggs, and sausage. 

The pancakes were chewy and hard to cut with the knife provided. The sausage was for some reason very very salty. So, salty I had to rip a piece of the pancake and wrap it around the sausage just to eat it. 

I'm normally nosh like crazy when hungover, but for some reason I could only stomach half of a pancake and one sausage. 

My friend and his fiancee both ordered the Big Scramble (beef w/ chopped onions, bell peppers, then scrambled with two eggs, served w/ hash browns and toast). They seemed to enjoy it, so I guess I just ordered the wrong thing.

SERVICE: Efficient; just what you expect from a typical diner.

I wouldn't make it a point to come back here. I rather go to Boogaloos and wait for 30+ minutes for their Chorizo Hash--YUM!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Service was eh.
Food was meh. (Pretty bland, needs more salt!)
Prices were average.
The only thing that saved this place was the silver dollar pancakes, because yummy!
3*
author: M S.

description: Food was good. Service was bad. 1st lady that talked to us gave me wrong information about the menu. Other lady employee ridiculously loud and obnoxious. They dropped the bill in the middle of my meal and then a man started mopping the floor with BLEACH while I was still eating. I couldnt even taste my food yet and started getting dizzy. I paid my bill and left. Pricing was cool. I only go to this place once in a while,I think there needs to be some sense of order in this "restaurant." .......P.S. i work in a restaurant.
author: Marie P.

description: This place is really dirty. I needed to wash my hands before eating. Their bathroom was located upstairs. The path to the bathroom was dirty and there was graffiti everywhere. The bathroom was absolutely disgusting. It was worst than a gas station bathroom.  Trash was overflowing, one of the windows was busted and they used tissue paper to cover the hole, dirt and grim everywhere. I have a hard time believing that cooks/servers are practicing good hygiene when their bathroom facilities are that nasty.
author: T O.

description:
Not good.  

Because of the crowd, I expected something special here.  All I got was bad coffee, even worse greasy spoon breakfast fare (overcooked eggs, flimsy toast, and greasy hashbrowns), and heartburn.

If you want a real solid hangover-killer, stick with Mission's Kitchen down the street.
author: Eric S.

description:
The service was friendly and welcoming.  The dining area feels very comfortable and it makes you want to linger for a while. The food, however, was just okay.  The coffee was awful, but I really needed it and it worked.

If you're just looking for basic breakfast, you might be satisfied with this place, but you definitely won't be impressed.
author: Hester B.

description: Jim's is your classic diner. And by classic I mean no frills great basics at a great price. The staff is the friendliest you will find. The clientele are pretty much the the people in th neighborhood. We roll into Jim's on a pretty regular schedule. And I have to add it is tough to even find a tuna melt on a menu anymore and the have it covered. Be sure to ask for the homemade salsa to top your eggs.
author: Carl C.

description:
Jim's isn't the kind of brunch place where you drink mimosa's, dine on small bites and enjoy the comfort of your sterile, ultra modern surroundings.

Jim's is a place where you get a huge breakfast of greasy bacon, eggs however you want and a stack of hotcakes for under $6.  To say it's similar to a Denny's (or a Waffle House for you Southerners) would be fair.

The difference is that the wait staff here RULES.  My diet coke never sunk toward the bottom half of the glass.  And they were quick to offer up ketchup and hot sauce.

Plus my waitress was talking about how happy hour was coming up.  It was 12:45.  "But we're not doing beer this time, we're doing vodka and pineapple soda."  A woman after my own heart if ever there was one.

Another waitresses, not even mine, came over and suggested that I try some ambiguous homemade green sauce on my eggs.  I couldn't understand her completely as her accent was rather thick but her love of that sauce was obvious and I tried some.  It was yummy.

Jim's, you're my new restaurant of choice for Sunday mornings when I need help recovering from a brutal Saturday night.  ktnxbai
author: Evan L.

description: Three cheers for a real greasy spoon, with greasy spoon food (plus avocado) and low prices, comfy booths, friendly service, and a great salad to sub the hashbrowns. It's dirty - it's straightforward - a homeless dude was sleeping with his face in his food - but that's part of the charm. To me.
author: Andrew K.

description: Kinda decent breakfast greasy spoon diner food. Just the type of food I love. Might find better tasting ingredients elsewhere but it wasn't really that bad. Just not outstanding. Might go back one day
author: Marc M.

description:
Back in the 80's Jim's was located in the Excelsior until a late night fire destroyed the restaurant.  If' I'm not mistaken this is where they moved to shortly after the fire.  I could be wrong, but I'm almost sure this is the case. 

The food wasn't bad, but I was expecting the old Jim's Menu.  I don't want to go into how they use to be, but can say that the breakfast today was just standard, and the menu was also really basic.  

Nothing to highlight here except condiments include Salsa and Jalapeno Peppers.
author: Eric D.

description:
As a native, I am always so proud of the wide variety of excellent restaurants we have here in San Francisco. My one gripe is that outside of Sparky's and The Lucky Penny (or The Hep C Palace as we like to call it), there is a sad and shocking lack of diners. I lived in NY for two years and got used to being able to get a big greasy breakfast any time of day or night. Not so here. Today I found Jim's. I was home.

My one complaint about Jim's is that it is only open from 7am to 3:30pm. These guys are missing a major opportunity here...the late night drunk hipsters would PACK this place 7 nights a week between 9pm and 3am. Truly. 

The ambiance is just what you want - old black booth line every wall and even some space in the middle of the restaurant. Formica tables. One waitress who is friendly enough but leaves you alone for the most part. Simple, straightforward menu. The tuna sandwich with fries was great - perfect, in fact. Bottomless iced tea. The tuna melt my co-worker had looked great as well. Perhaps the best part? The prices! $5.50 for a great lunch! Can't beat that with a stick. Well, you could, but it wouldn't taste very good afterward.

Oh! And the people watching and overheard conversations are PRICELESS.

I love Jim's. Its my new favorite place. I just wish they were open at 2:00am. I hate Sparkys.
author: Amber M.

description:
This place is, " Pretty good for the money  ". If you don't feel up to making your own BASIC breakfast.....this is the place.

Tip: It's cash only.
author: Ritz R.

description: This has been a secret of my friend's for about a year now. Basically it's what you would expect from a diner .. I know it's rare, but diner food. There wasn't a quail egg made with the omelettes or toast that brioche, it was toast. Basically I think I found the diner I was looking for in SF. You go in, there is ripped booth seating and some tables throughout. A very friendly staff. I discovered that they make a really good chicken fried steak here too. (Nice batter and their gravy is really good too, lots of turkey). I am quite happy with this place and will be back again soon.
author: Greg G.

description: This is a slightly different take from my other "go to"  cheap breakfast in the Mission, Valencia.  Jim's, like Valencia, gives you big ass portions for cheap!  The service is great...very friendly with a family atmosphere.  I just love greasy spoon joints...what can I say.  I've tried the chicken fried steak and their eggs benedict...booyaaa, their both good.
author: Ramon L.

description:
I love this place because it is so plain and straightforward and wonderfully CHEAP.  I used to live on Folsom btwn 20th and 21st, in a house full of vegetarians who didn't really appreciate the lingering aromas of a morning eggs and bacon fry-up.  

One more excuse to hike on down to Jims, tuck into a booth all by my lonesome for a leisurely brekkie around 10:00 am--my favorite time for breakfast.  I can sit and read the Chron and the NY Times and slowly eat Eggs over easy (or maybe poached) with bacon, hash browns (NO COUNTRY FRIES!!), rye toast, hot tea and milk, and OJ.  And if I'm hungover, an ice-cold Pepsi.

The waitresses are efficient with refills, the food is almost always quick, and it's just the right portion.  I don't eat huge amounts of food at one time, and I get kind of grossed out by overly large Denny's style sized breakfasts.  I can't eat that much and I'd rather have a smallish CHEAP breakfast than a huge he-man plate that goes for $7.95.

Only drawback--the bathrooms, up a narrow flight of stairs, are truly horrific.  

Otherwise, it's a no-gimmick, nice and plain place to have your all American breakfast.
author: Andrea W.

description:
I keep opening my refrigerator to find edamame beans and an assortment of condiments.  We have self cleaning ovens why can't they make self filling refrigerators?  The oven is next to my fridge.  Why can't some of that self cleaning capacity rub off on my lazy-ass refrigerator?

Anyway as per usual, I awoke after an evening of 'Networking' and 'Strategic Relationship building' with a hangover and an empty-ass refrigerator (Why did I move out of my parent's house? Oh yea cuz they kicked me out for eating all of their food).

So Kelly V. (my equally hungover couch guest) and I eased on down the road to Jim's.  .  You can't screw bacon and eggs up too badly which is why I have a fondest for diner's.

There is a bit of a weird smell but, you get used to it.
The bacon is thick.  ( I dont know what Jeremy W. is talking bout)
The coffee here is crap so, I avoid it here.
Don't be afraid to order water, its cold and not tap.
They are lightening fast with the food. v. good.

Overall- decent, cheap eats.  But, I'd suggest you make sure not to look in the direction of the old toothless lady who frequents (or should I say HAUNTS this diner).
author: R M.

description:
Who is Jim?  And what possessed him to open up this place a block away from my house?  I DIG this place.  The dude I went with thought this place was disgusting, but I enjoyed it.  It reminded me of being in Bakersfield or Gilroy or something.

I ordered the eggs benedict but asked for fries instead of the hash browns and bacon instead of ham.  I'm a gross eater.  I order Pepsi for breakfast and eat my fries with a side of mayo and ranch.  It was pretty awesome.  The price was good and the food was tasty, and it's a block away from my house.  The Hollandaise sauce tasted kinda like the nacho cheese you'd get from 7-11, but I was all about it.  I'd rather go here than Mission Kitchen for sure.  AND, they have corned beef hash for dinner!

FYI, I'm on a mission to find the best corned beef hash in the city.  So far, M's Kitchen or Cafe in the Sunset is in the lead.  Any tips?

Hurray for Jim's!  I'll be back.
author: Meh M.

description:
If you share my enchantment with the charm of places like Waffle House, then you'll like Jim's.  Jim's has aged gracefully from contemporary to retro, no painted on nostalgia here.  It's the real deal.

The food is solid, plentiful and filling.  The service is good.  Try it, you'll like it.**





**The pancakes are a tad rubbery though.
author: Linda L.

description: It was 1958 and I was ten years old the first time I set foot in the Mission District's newest eatery, Jim's Restaurant, which is  just around the corner from where I grew up!  I thought it was great then what with its ultramodern tricolored light fixtures (which are still there), the exotic plastic plants, and the great food.  A lot has changed in the Mission over the years and so has Jim's but it continues to serve up good food at great prices.  I no longer live in San Francisco but whenever I visit, I always try to stop in for one of Jim's great breakfasts!   Keep it going!  iPaseme los jalapenos, por favor!
author: Philip G.

description: For a neighborhood greasy-spoon place, it's good. No fancy stuff here, but good and good portion sizes: good-sized pancakes and 4 (!) strips of bacon with their Country Breakfast. As another reviewer noted, the chicken-fried steak is also pretty good.
author: Paul L.

description:
Pulp Fiction.

That's the first thing I think of when I walk in here.

It looks just like the cafe that the couple hold up in the movie! The quintessential greasy spoon coffee shop / diner / breakfast spot. It looks totally 70s still, which is cool :)

The food is not so great, but hey, it'll get you full and its pretty cheap.

The service- hit or miss.

Overall I'm a fan. You should check 'er out.
author: Kai S.

description:
Jim's Restaurant should realistically be called Jim's Diner. Maybe Jim's Coffee Shop. What you'll find here are big greazy omlettes, pancakes that weigh on you heavily and watery coffee that will nonetheless stiffen your neck by your third cup. Big booths and a decent sized counter.

Bacon is thin, but usually crispy. If you order one of their dinners, you are weird. Why would you eat dinner at a place that is only open for breakfast and lunch? Stick with meals that come with potatoes &/or toast. Their most "citified" serving here is prolly Eggs Benedict. If they ever go Florentine, I'll know Jim's has gone Hollywood.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
I FOUND IT! I FINALLY FOUND MY DINER!!!

A friend and I wandered in here Sunday morning, seeking a true diner experience, and we certainly were NOT dissappointed. 

See, I come from the Midwest. I come from the land of greasy road-side diners, full of buttery-golden hashbrowns, greasy eggs, buttered toast and dirty-sock coffee. Sometimes, I'm feeling nostalgic and I need it here. I've been on the SEARCH since I moved here nearly a YEAR ago for the equivalent of my old haunt in St. Louis (THE BUTTERY, it was called....oh, man....my mouth waters just THINKING about it). The problem out here is that price gets out of hand. Who the hell does a diner think it is when it's charging $6 for some egg, potato, and bread? GIVE ME A BREAK!

So, I wandered in here, assuming the worst/expecting the same thing I've gotten all around town. 

You choose your own table here, and there's plenty to choose from. The barstools don't even look uncomfortable. The waitress was right there for us just seconds after we sat, asking if we'd like some coffee. 

And then I saw it: $3.95 for two eggs, toast, and hashbrowns. Oh, Jim...I'll have your babies, now.

So...we dined. Our food was out a mere 5-10 minutes or so after ordering, and they were pretty busy! 

The food was perfect. OH, how you could taste the butter in the 'browns. The eggs were immaculate, perfecting the definition of "sunny side up." The toast was buttered and served with one packet of jame PER PIECE...no cheapskates here. 

My friend got the chicken-fried steak. He said it was exactly what he'd hoped for.

Our server was great. She kept my friend's coffee filled the entire time and she didn't hoover over us. 

The whole experience was great and I'm SO excited to find my new lazy-morning haunt. 

It's too bad they close so early :(  The Buttery was 24 hours...imagine a trip there, drunk, at 3 a.m. OH, yum.
author: Danyell K.

description: Best portions for a great price. Love the eggs benedict with their green salsa. Always leave with a clean plate.
author: Joanna A.

description:
It's not very fun waking up early in the morning after a long night of drinking and karaoke to discover it's actually Tuesday and you did all that drinking and ear-shattering singing on a Monday night like some crazy person who doesn't work.  (Okay, so I AM a crazy person who didn't have to work on Tuesday, but let's not get into semantics, here...)  It's even worse to discover that the friend whose house you crashed at has no food in the fridge save for some dressing and a pack of edamame beans (your friend's not too thrilled about it either).

But such a morning is easily salvaged with breakfast at Jim's.  The food is cheap, filling, decently tasty and served quickly, and the place is a complete dive, which means you won't feel uncomfortable or out of place for having a hangover or still wearing the dirty clothes you had on last night.

Four stars for Jim, who kept me and my friend from going hungry!
author: Kelly V.

description:
Cheap, fast, clean, tasty, and friendly.  Even better, no wait for a booth at 11am on a Sunday!  Everything you could want in your local greasy spoon.  This place epitomizes everything great about a neighborhood diner. We'll be back some lazy Sunday morning...

Four stars 'cause, like, it shouldn't be quite that easy.
author: Eclipse T.

description:
My rating strategy is simple: I rate a place on it's own terms. A pizza joint can get five stars if it serves up an exemplary version of a particular type of pie, while a high-end foodie restaurant can garner four or fewer stars if, say, the vaunted service is inattentive or an entree is delayed or whatever. You get the idea. While I prefer not to give either five- or one-star ratings, it's all relative to what the restaurant is, what it aspires to be, and what it should be.

Jim's earns four stars from me. I'd give it another half star if I could. Jim's is, aspires to be, and should be a classic American diner. With pleather booths, a long counter with swivel stools and ginormous indoor plants, it looks every bit like something in the Central Valley or the Midwest. It also tastes and costs right: classic American diner fare at a reasonable price. The service is warm and attentive--we were there recently during a shift change, and both our waitresses were great. 

This isn't the stuff of which foodie dreams are made, but when you want a greasy-spoon experience (c'mon, you know sometimes you really want it) in a fun and unpretentious environment, you really cannot go wrong with one of the all-day breakfast combos here.
author: Raoul U.

description: It was starting to rain and the line was long at Bugaloo's -- so we decided to try Jim's. Half the price and very decent diner fare. I had sunny side up, hash browns, sourdough toast and my friend had an omelette, wheat toast and hash browns and latte. All served quickly and friendly service. I could tell there was further Bugaloos spillover when a group of hipsters wearing racoon hats walked in.
author: Vanessa H.

description: Nice little breakfast place. Pancakes here are awesome. Sausages and eggs are tasty. Service was pretty good - got our food pretty quickly. Only reason I'm giving this four stars is because the portion of eggs and sausages on my plate seemed a little small for the price I paid. Otherwise, nice place! Would definitely eat here again next time I have the chance. :)
author: Michael S.

description:
Classic American style diner, very busy on th weekends. The food is pretty much straight up diner food... I went for the pancakes.. can't go too wrong with pancakes.

Service was reasonably fast, but can't be faulted with the amount of people in there. Staff were very friendly and was kinda funny hearing their small stories inbetween coffee filter changes.

This place will be high on my list of hangover cures ;)
author: Patrick W.

description:
I love breakfast but I couldn't finish mine.  I've never had such salty sausages in my life, and there was way too much butter in the hash browns.

I wanted to love it and will definitely try again in a couple of months but for now it gets a big booo from me.
author: Rachel N.

description: This is NO greasy spoon! When you hear the words greasy spoon you conjure up the image of, well, grease! At least grease, and maybe an old fry cook who cooks everything in a "hash". This place was just a step above Denny's in my opinion. The service wasn't impressive, the toast was just warm bread, my side of fruit was sitting in a bowl of its own juice and the OJ was most definitely from concentrate. They were fast and inexpensive so if you were in a rush I'd recommend it but to choose to go here of your own volition? Meh... I mean it's not the worst, but it is most certainly not the best. Just what you might be stuck with. I probably won't go back when other places are closer and far superior. If you like simple cheap and fast try it out, but don't be expecting a city paced greasy spoon or food that surprises you. Just make sure your expectations are in line.
author: aaron c.

description: Nice standard burger & fries.  Prob here 3 times a week.
author: John C.

description:
They roast a fresh turkey every Thursday, when you order a turkey sandwich they ask if you want white or dark meat... for a five dollar sandwich that comes with fries they do a great job. Mmmmm roasted turkey!
It is a basic diner, nothing fancy in any form and the prices are totally affordable
author: Reviewchick C.

description: A girl at the shoe place across the street recommended Jims to us. GREAT service,  super cheap and delicious food. They don't hold back on the hashbrowns. We ordered hot chocolate and it was really good and not the powdery cocoa stuff. :)
author: Tina P.

description: If I manage to crawl out of bed before it closes, Jim's is my favorite way to cure my inevitable hangover when I've spent all of my hard earned dollars on booze the night before. Also, at a mindbending two blocks away, I don't exactly have to drag myself very far. Order your hash browns extra crispy... you'll thank me. Possibly.
author: katharine s.

description:
When you wake up past noon on a Saturday, it's not always easy to find a good breakfast place that will still greet you with, "good morning!" at 2:10pm.  This is what I found at Jim's.  Literally, I looked at my watch right after she said it.

Also, when I found my seat I was greeted by the daughter of one of the servers.  She must have been five or six, and she placed my utensils on my table.  When I thanked her she responded with a you're welcome, and, as someone who works with children on a regular basis and knows how lacking in manners a majority of them are, I was quite impressed.

I got the two egg breakfast with bacon, and it was everything that you could expect from a diner breakfast.  The bacon looked a little weird but tasted fantastic.  It also came with hashbrowns and toast, and the hashbrowns made the meal.  So good.  My tummy felt a little funny afterwards, but that's to be expected from a good ol' all American greasy breakfast.

Of course, the price was another huge plus.  My boyfriend's and my meal came to a total of twenty bucks with the tip even though we both got large juices and he got a side.  You can't beat prices like that.  I wish I could have tipped the little girl too, but unfortunately she and her mother had left by the time we were done with our meal.
author: Laura W.

description:
I adore Jim's.  It's not that the food is so great, but it's convenient and you can't beat the booths for a cozy weekend breakfast spot.

One star for the sailor and hooker couple we spotted there one early morn a few years back.  They were doing the cozy booth thing, but a little too cozy if you get my drift!
author: .Hon H.

description: a lot for a little.  Best hashbrowns in town.  Full breakfast eggs, sausage or bacon and hashbrowns for $5.04 plus tax and tip.
author: Anibel B.

description:
I am a firm believer that 2-egg breakfasts should be under $5 and yet I kept coming across all these lovely little diners scattered about the city that had them for over $6 at least. It was my one beef with the city.  Well now Jim's, a mere few blocks from my house, has ameliorated this issue. This is the greatest seedy cheap diner in the mission/castro. It doesn't apologize for itself and doesn't try to be anything more than it is and I appreciate that. 

Warning: don't plop down on the plush-looking booths. They are actually not and I have the butt bruises to prove it.
author: Geryon R.

description: Good breakfast on a Sunday morning after a long Saturday night BBQ.  After wandering about the Mission looking for a place to get our meal on, we crossed this place.  Got there right on time, so we got seated quickly.  Staff was pretty friendly and our orders were correct.  MMMMM....Jalepen-O's(good cereal!-see pic)!!!
author: andrew l.

description:
If you're looking for good and cheap diner food, this is the spot.  I didn't want some foo foo breakfast after a hard night, so I nestled into the leather booths here and had a ground beef scramble with hash brown, toast and bottomless coffee.

Doesn't look like much from the outside, but its a gem.  Also, great service.  Try their home made green hot sauce, its a winner.
author: Mathias G.

description: The best breakfast spot I found in San Francisco with the best salsa.  The coffee was right on and the service was great.  They had personality and they were fast.  Not to say that they've lost any of that since I've been there.  If your in the mission area, check it out. it's worth the visit!!!!!
author: Rikki S.

description: very standard dinner, had jims deluxe burger which was good for the price but difficult to eat on the french roll. the overall experience was nothing special in my mind, but prices were good will eat again.
author: Manuel A.

description:
When I was a kid (long time ago), my auntie used to take me here for breakfast as a treat. Diner food as a treat? Hmm that's when I must have started packing the pounds on. . .
So, I'm quite nostalgic about it. Besides those occasional 1980s (okay maybe some 70s too) mornings, I still like this place. Good diner food and generous portions. Nothing fancy just greasy spoon diner food. I love it. I have to admit not all my friends seem to be as fond of it as I am, but like I always say, "what do they know".
author: Theresa C.

description: an honest breakfast, with honest prices and friendly staff. i wish they were open 24/7.
author: Ameer N.

description: Classic food for super cheap and great service! Can't wait to go back and try the fried chicken, but for now, I've found a go-to classic breakfast spot right in my hood.
author: Ian K.

description:
I had my first experience here after living around the corner for a year.  It definitely lives up to the greasy diner appeal.  Had the bacon, avocado, cheese omelet and i liked that the avocado was whole and yummy.  someone else complained about it not being chopped up but i like it nice and chunky.  also - service was great.  our waitress was so sweet.  

they bring you a huge bowl of chilies too and the most amazing chili sauce for the hashbrowns which were so yummy.

good hungover food!
author: Holly S.

description: My favorite, reliable greasy spoon in the Mission. Service is friendly. Foods tasty and inexpensive and its always the same. Its really comfortable in there.
author: Hilde L.

description: Great diner food for good prices.
author: Carmine R.

description: food is inexpensive  and good but the only draw back is the restroom!  It's horrible!  I was spooked when I went up those stairs and surprised and disappointed to see a yucky looking and vandalized restroom. what is the owner thinking? How could the owner let the place look that way.I would be embarrassed if it were my business. Why hasn't the Health Department forced the owner to clean it up? i really don't care to go back to that place.   its too bad. But i guess the location is what keeps the prices reasonably low.
author: Lucy H.

description: It's just basic greasy goodness. The place is not a scene, there is no wait and the staff is friendly and attentive. In short, it's the perfect place for a hangover.
author: German F.

description:
Before I launch into why this sucked, I'll preface my review with the fact that this was a to-go order. I only spent 5 min inside and didn't really get a grasp on the atmosphere or the staff. 

So.. I woke up and I wanted pancakes or a waffle or french toast. I definitely didn't want a breakfast burrito which is so readily available in my hood. Boogaloo's was not taking to-go orders because it was too busy. And as much as I love Boogaloo's, I simply didn't have to patience to wait in that line. 

"Yelp! Yelp would lead me to a comparable substitute" - I thought. Yelp lead me to Jim's Restaurant which is 2 blocks from my house and the menu is ample with all of my cravings. I got the waffle with two strips of bacon and strawberry preserves with whipped cream on the side.  

Uhmmm yeah... I should have either gotten a breakfast burrito or waited for my beloved Boogaloos. I am pretty sure that the soles of my trusty 5 year-old grey converses have more flavor and a better texture than the waffle I ordered. 

Don't get me started on the bacon. I think it was made yesterday. 

Don't get me started on the strawberry preserves either. They were red. I think that's the only thing that they have in common with a strawberry. 

So yeah.. Jim's... please make better food. I'd like to like you and I'd like to eat at your establishment. ... So pretty pleaaaaase? With a cherry on top?
author: A K.

description: The food here is not that great.  If you like this place you ain't fat.  This place is known for the steak sandwich.  I ordered it once and it was so chewy I lost 100lbs from excessive chewing.  The best thing here are the burgers and pancakes.  I can make everything else at home including the pancakes and burgers.  This place is on the more expensive side for a diner.  If the food was cheaper I would give it a 3 stars.  But for price to value its not that great.
author: Fatty A.

description: While the sheep stand in line for an hour at Boogaloos I'll walk right up to the counter at Jim's and have a nice old fashioned standard breakfast.
author: Manny F.

description: I have a question...Does anyone out there know if this is the same Jim's Restaurant as the one that was once located on Mission Street by Brazil Street?  It had burnt down years ago and greasy spoon or not, it was a great, inexpensive place to hang out, get a quick cheap breakfast and coffee and be on my merry way.  If it is...then my rating stands.
